A quadratic residue modulo n is an integer that is congruent to a perfect square modulo n. To find all quadratic residues modulo 13, we need to compute the squares of the numbers from 0 to 12 (since 13 is a prime number) and then reduce them modulo 13.

0² ≡ 0 (mod 13)
1² ≡ 1 (mod 13)
2² ≡ 4 (mod 13)
3² ≡ 9 (mod 13)
4² ≡ 16 ≡ 3 (mod 13)
5² ≡ 25 ≡ 12 (mod 13)
6² ≡ 36 ≡ 10 (mod 13)
7² ≡ 49 ≡ 10 (mod 13)
8² ≡ 64 ≡ 12 (mod 13)
9² ≡ 81 ≡ 3 (mod 13)
10² ≡ 100 ≡ 9 (mod 13)
11² ≡ 121 ≡ 4 (mod 13)
12² ≡ 144 ≡ 1 (mod 13)

Now, we can list the distinct residues obtained:

0, 1, 3, 4, 9, 10, 12

So, the quadratic residues modulo 13 are {0, 1, 3, 4, 9, 10, 12}.
